math-outreach-notes/math-circle-notes/br.title: Lesson 1 - Mathematical Braids
math-outreach-notes/math-circle-notes/br.description:
Able to describe how the physical notion of braids influences its mathematical definition Able to show how braids can form a mathematical object called a group Know a few applications of mathematical braids to the sciences In this lecture series we're going to explore how braids can be interpreted mathematically, and how these mathematical interpretations and abstractions help us solve other real world problems. We'll start today with getting on the same page with what we mean by braids, before seeing if we can turn our physical intuition into a precise mathematical statement.Using a dowel or wooden bar, tie strips of colourful ribbon or string to the dowel, at least 1 meter in length, and hang the dowel up. Fig 1. A visual of five coloured ribbons (red, pink, blue, cyan, and green, from left to right) hanging from a dowel, which is itself supported by a blue string attached to a pin.We can think of the ribbons as representing everyday things we braid with, such as our hair, thread and yarn in knitting and crocheting, ropes, wicker baskets, and even bread! Braids are also closely related to knots and tangles, which appear in art, jewelry, and architecture throughout cultures across the world. A braid then involves wrapping the ribbons around each other, and then fixing the ends of the ribbons once we've finished wrapping:
Fig 2. A visual of five coloured ribbons (red, pink, blue, cyan, and green, from left to right) hanging from a dowel, which is itself supported by a blue string attached to a pin, as in Figure 1. The ribbons are know wrapped over and under each other, with the red ribbon wrapping under the pink ribbon, and the blue and cyan ribbons wrapping under the green ribbon.The reason why we need to fix the bottoms of the ribbons after braiding them is that otherwise the ends could just slide back to the original hanging position, but these should be two different braids. This raises the important question, that is also foundational to a lot of mathematics, which is what would it mean for two braids to be equivalent? They should involve the same number of ribbons We should be able to bend ribbons as long as the ends are fixed, without changing the braid This leads to our first informal, but mathematical, definition of a braid:Braids as Strings in 3D An -braid for an integer is a collection of strings in -space, which are disjoint (i.e. they do not intersect), and monotone (in the direction). The th braid starts at the point and ends at the point , for some possibly different integer . Two braids will be said to be equivalent if one can be deformed to the other without moving endpoints or intersecting strings. Note: The monotonicity requirement ensures that we can't knot a single ribbon with itself, which would not be a braid (but would be something called a tangle!).Exercise Determine if the two Braids below are equivalent or not given what we've discussed so far:
Fig 3. Two dowels with five ribbons hanging off each of them, coloured red, pink, blue, cyan, and green, respectively. The ribbons on either dowel are braided together in a variety of ways. What about the two braids Fig 4. Two dowels with five ribbons hanging off each of them, coloured red, pink, blue, cyan, and green, respectively. The ribbons on either dowel are braided together in a variety of ways. Using the variable to indicate the direction our braids our going suggests another mathematical model for braids, which helps us get closer to a more precise mathematical definition.Braids as Time Histories or Particle Dances An -braid for an integer is the time history of a collection of non-colliding particles in 2D space. More precisely, an -braid is a collection of continuous functions such that , and for all times if . This definition motivates the visualization of walking along strings as they are built up into a braid.Ribbon Activity Each student gets a length of ribbon, with one end tapped to the ground under their feet. The students then walk in a path while unraveling the string or ribbon behind themselves before returning to one of the starting points, the whole time avoiding colliding with other students. Question What do the orientations of the crossings tell you about the particle paths? Pulling your ribbon tight, see how the paths change, while giving you an equivalent, although visually very different, braid An important benefit of the particle dance perspective for braids is that it's easier to formalize what it means for two braids to be equivalent. Explicitly, we will say that an -braid is equivalent to an -braid if we have a family of continuous functionsso that , , and for all , is itself an -braid. The collection of functions can be thought of as a continuous family of braids. The first factor keeps track of the time evolution for the braids, while the second factor keeps track where we are in the family of braids. We can also think of the second factor as indicating how much we've deformed our initial braids so far.Now that we have some initial proposals for mathematical ways of formalizing braids, we can start investigating what types of properties and structures these braids have.Exercise On a sheet of paper, or using strips of ribbon and tape, make a braid with 3 strings. Then at the bottom of the previous braid make another braid. We can view the result as a composite braid, though based on our formalism we have to be a bit careful, since our time should only go from to . To deal with the time issue, we can speed up the rate at which we trace the braids. In the particle model this means that for two braids and , their composite can be defined by taking the th trajectory to be The fact that we defined two braids to be equivalent if we can slide the strings to go from one presentation to another, while fixing endpoints, ensures that this definition doesn't depend on how we split up the interval . For example, we could trace the first braid in 1/3rd the time, and then the second braid in the remaining 2/3rds of the time:We could even take a brake in the middle before tracing the second braid On Board: Draw out these examples, and/or use the ribbons. In particular, the wiggling invariance ensures that we can put a collection of braids together two at a time, and the end result doesn't depend which pairs we put together first Draw on Board to clarify Additionally, if we paste any braid with the braid of just straight ribbons, nothing happens. This tells us that braids can be given the structure of a group.Group A group consists of a collection of objects , thought of as symmetries of some underlying structure, together with a distinguished symmetry and a composition operation combining two symmetries. This data is subject to the following conditions: The distinguished symmetry is the do-nothing symmetry in the sense that for any other symmetry , . For every symmetry in , an inverse symmetry such that . The order in which a sequence of symmetries is combined two-at-a-time is independent of the resulting combined symmetry. For example, given a triple of symmetries in , we have the equality of symmetries Example The integers with addition is a group. The rotational symmetries of a square (or triangle, circle, etc.) form a group. The set of non-zero fractions forms a group with multiplication. The permutations of -points form a group Translations of the plane form a group Question Does the order in which we paste braids matter? Yes!! This means that the braid group, , is not a commutative group.

reading-notes/homotopy-theory/k-theory/v.description:
In this note we aim to provide a more formal introduction to the theory of vector bundles on smooth manifolds following Chapter 10 in Lee's Smooth Manifolds[1]. This work generalizes the theory of the tangent bundle on manifolds.Consider a topological space throughout.Vector Bundle A real vector bundle of rank over is a topological space together with a surjective continuous map satisfying the following conditions: For each , the fiber over is endowed with the structure of a -dimensional vector space. For each , there exists a neighborhood of in and a homeomorphism , called a local trivialization of over , satisfying (i.e. is a bundle map over ) For each , the restriction is an isomorphism of vector spaces. The space is called the total space of the bundle, is called its base, and is its projection.
Note that a real vector bundle is precisely a locally trivial fibration (c.f. Basics of Fiber Bundles and Principal BundlesBasics of Fiber Bundles and Principal Bundles) with fiber , and with a choice of atlas such that the transition functions are linear isomorphisms on the fibers.If and are smooth manifolds with or without boundary, is a smooth map, and the local trivializations can be chosen to be diffeomorphisms, then is called a smooth vector bundle and any local trivialization that is a diffeomorphism is called a smooth local trivialization.We usually refer to rank-1 vector bundles as (real) line bundles. If we replace with above, and require all vector spaces to be -vector spaces, we obtain the notion of a complex vector bundle. In this note we will restrict to considering real vector bundles.Smooth Vector Bundle Maps are Submersions Suppose is a smooth vector bundle. Then is a surjective smooth submersion. Proof. For , we can take a smooth local trivializations . Then we have that for all , by the chain rule. Since is a smooth submersion, being a projection, and is a diffeomorphism, it follows that is surjective, and in particular is a smooth submersion. *** If there exists a global trivialization of a vector bundle , we will say that is a trivial bundle. If is a smooth bundle admitting a smooth global trivialization, we say that the bundle is smoothly trivial. For the remainder of the note we will primary be restricting to smooth bundles and smooth trivializations.Product Bundle If , then , the projection, is naturally a rank -real vector bundle called the product bundle, and by construction is trivial. If is a smooth manifold with or without boundary, then is smoothly trivial. Mobius Bundle Define an equivalence relation on by if and only if for some integer . Then has a projection map , the sphere, using the isomorphism . If is the quotient map, if , then is still a quotient map, so we can think of as the space obtained from the strip given by taking a half-twist of the right-hand side and pasting the result with the left-hand side. For any , the image under of the rectangle is a smooth compact manifold with boundary referred to as a Mobius band. It turns out we can endow with a unique smooth structure such that is a smooth covering map and is a smooth real line bundle over , called the Mobius bundle. In particular, the local trivializations of can be interpreted as coordinate charts for the smooth structure on . Tautological Bundle The tautological line bundle is defined by with component-wise addition and scalar multiplication. Similarly, we have the tautological complex line bundle defined by In either case the trivializing neighborhoods are given by , for , with trivialization so that the transition functions are given by which gives the cocycle formula . Note that these are smooth (resp. holomorphic), so the tautological line bundles are smooth (resp. holomorphic) vector bundles. As mentioned at the start, the vector bundles of primary interest for us are the tangent bundles of smooth manifolds.The Tangent Bundle as a Vector Bundle Let be a smooth -manifold with or without boundary. Then is a smooth vector bundle of rank over . Proof. Let be a smooth chart for . Then we have the associated smooth chart on , given by Composing with then gives our desired smooth local trivialization, and further since each are linear maps, restricts to linear maps on fibers. *** Note that from the above construction the transition functions for are given by for a given atlas on .Spheres Note that through the canonical embedding we can realized as the bundle with total space Then give the localizing neighborhoods for the trivializations where projects away the th coordinate. We now begin describing transition functions between smooth local trivializations.Transition Maps for Smooth Trivializations Let be a smooth vector bundle of rank over . Suppose and are smooth local trivializations with . Then there exists a smooth map such that the composite is given by Proof. First, note that we have a commutative diagram
We then define by which is smooth in each component and hence is smooth into , and since the columns form a basis the image lands in , and hence co-restricts to a smooth map since is an embedded submanifold. ***
The smooth map in Intro to Vector Bundles on Manifolds > ^0a90b8Intro to Vector Bundles on Manifolds > ^0a90b8 is referred to as the transition function between the local trivializations.Let's now consider how we can construct smooth vector bundles in general.Vector Bundle Chart Lemma Let be a smooth manifold with or without boundary and suppose for each we have a real vector bundle of some fixed dimension . Let and let be the natural projection. Suppose that we are given the following data: An open cover of for each , a bijection whose restriction to each is a vector space isomorphism for each with , a smooth map such that for all Then has a unique topology and smooth structure making it into a smooth manifold with or without boundary and a smooth rank- vector bundle over with as projection and as smooth local trivializations. Proof. The first part of the claim follows from the associated smooth chart lemma for manifolds, and by construction the coordinate charts are local trivializations of the resulting vector bundle. *** Whitney Sums Given smooth vector bundles and of ranks and , respectively. We can define their Whitney sum to be , with the natural projection . For , choose a neighborhood of small enough that we have local trivializations and for the two bundles. Then we have given by If and are the transition functions for the two bundles, then by construction the transition function for their Whitney sum is given by the direct sum , which is smooth as each component is smooth. We can also give an alternate description of the Whitney sum using pullbacks of vector bundles.Pulling back smooth bundles Let be a smooth vector bundle of rank and let be a smooth map. Then the pullback of the co-span in exists and is a rank vector bundle over , with the pullback square being a morphism of vector bundles. Proof.
By Intro to Vector Bundles on Manifolds > ^a4ea93Intro to Vector Bundles on Manifolds > ^a4ea93 we have that the map is a submersion, and hence and are transverse, . Therefore, by Embeddings and Transversality > ^115ea9Embeddings and Transversality > ^115ea9 we have that is an embedded submanifold of of codimension . Thus, we have a pullback diagram of smooth manifolds
In particular, , being the pullback of a smooth submersion, is itself a smooth submersion. Now, note that for , as sets, so we can define the vector space structure of the fiber via this isomorphism. We define the restriction of to to be with induced projection and trivializations. Formally, we can realize as the pullback of along the inclusion . Given a smooth manifold and a submanifold , we refer to the restricted bundle as the ambient tangent bundle over . Let be a vector bundle throughout. Recall a section of is a section in the category (or whatever category the bundle lives in) which is simply a map such that (i.e. it is a lift of the identity along ). A local section of is a lift of an open inclusion . We will refer to such a section as rough if it is only a section on the level of set functions (i.e. not necessarily smooth or even continuous).The support of a section is defined as the closure of the set .Zero Section If is a vector bundle, the zero section is continuous, and is smooth if is smooth. It is a continuous map such that for each . When is tangent to at every point, this is exactly a vector field on . These operations are smooth since they are smooth on the level of local trivializations.Sheaf of Sections of a Vector Bundle Let be a smooth vector bundle. Then is a sheaf of -modules. Proof. Further, since this operation is defined pointwise it satisfies the axioms of a module inherited from the vector space axioms for the fiber. Further, restriction is restriction of functions, and so naturally commutes with this pointwise module structure.
It remains to show that satisfies the sheaf condition. However, this is precisely Smooth Maps and Smooth Partitions of Unity > ^c234f7Smooth Maps and Smooth Partitions of Unity > ^c234f7. *** Extension Lemma for Vector Bundles Let be a smooth vector bundle over a smooth manifold with or without boundary. Suppose is a closed subset of and is a section of that is smooth in the sense that extends to a smooth local section of in a neighborhood of each point. For each open subset containing , there exists a global smooth section such that and . Proof. For each let be an open neighborhood of and let be a smooth local section extending . Let for all . Then by Intro to Vector Bundles on Manifolds > ^3c0c92Intro to Vector Bundles on Manifolds > ^3c0c92 is smooth and so can be extended to a smooth global section with .As with the special case of the tangent bundle, we can talk about local and global frames of vector bundles more generally.Linearly Independent and Spanning Sections A -tuple of local sections of a vector bundle over (open) is said to be linearly independent if is linearly independent in for all . Similarly, they span if their values span for each . A local frame for over is an ordered -tuple of linearly independent local sections over that span . If this is called a global frame.Completion of Local Frames Suppose is a smooth vector bundle of rank . If is a linearly independent -tuple of smooth local sections of over an open subset , with , then for each there exist smooth sections defined on some neighborhood of such that is a smooth local frame for over . Proof.

By Intro to Vector Bundles on Manifolds > ^3c0c92Intro to Vector Bundles on Manifolds > ^3c0c92 we can extend to local sections . Next, there exists a trivialization with and . Then we have a smooth map given by At this lands in by construction, so as this subset is open in , we obtain an open neighborhood of such that the restriction of this map to has image contained in . In particular, it follows that form a local frame about extending .(2) The same argument in the second part of (1) yields the desired result using the fact that full rank matrices form an open subspace.
(3) follows from Intro to Vector Bundles on Manifolds > ^3c0c92Intro to Vector Bundles on Manifolds > ^3c0c92 as well as the argument in the second paragraph of (1), using the fact that full rank matrices form an open subspace. *** As the proof of these last two theorems showed, local frames for vector bundles are intimately connected with their local trivializations. Let's see some examples that also illustrate this:Global Frame for a Product Bundle If is the trivial bundle, then any basis or yields a global frame defined by . Local Frame Associated with Local Trivializations Suppose is a smooth vector bundle. In the last example we used a general phenomenon that we can push-forward smooth sections of vector bundles along bundle homomorphisms.Local Frames Local Trivializations There is a one-to-one correspondence between local trivializations of a vector bundle and local frames. reading-notes/homotopy-theory/k-theory/v.title: Orientations and the Thom Isomorphism
reading-notes/homotopy-theory/k-theory/v.description:
In this note we provide an introduction the Thom isomorphism and some of its important consequences following the work of Milnor and Stasheff in their book on Characteristic Classes[1]. We begin with a discussion on oriented bundles before surveying the Thom isomorphism, Euler classes, Thom spaces, and Stiefel-Whitney classes.Notation: Throughout we write for the Eilenberg-MacLane spectrum of a ring (or more generally abelian group) . If is a vector bundle, we write for the corresponding total space.To motivate our definition of an orientation for a vector bundle let's begin with a single vector space.Orientation on a vector space Let be a real vector space of dimension . An orientation of is an equivalence class of bases, where two (ordered) bases and are equivalent if and only if their change of basis matrix has positive determinant. Every vector space has two distinct orientations. We often equip with its canonical orientation given by the equivalence class containing the standard ordered basis .
Previously we've discussed orientations in the context of simplices when defining simplicial and singular homology in Basics of Homology - Simplicial and Singular HomologyBasics of Homology - Simplicial and Singular Homology. To see how these are related, let be an -simplex which is linearly embedded in the -dimensional vector space with ordered vertices . Then forms a basis on corresponding to an orientation of the vector space.We can interpret a choice of orientation for as a choice of one of the two possible generators for the singular homology groups To see this let denote the standard -simplex with canonically ordered vertices. Choose some orientation preserving linear embedding which maps the barycenter of to the zero vector, and hence the boundary of into . Then is a singular -simplex representing an element in the group of relative -cycles . The homology class of this -cycle is now the preferred generator for the homology group .Similarly, using dual bases we obtain a preferred generator of the cohomology group . We could also use a LES argument as in the following:Relative Cohomology of For a ring , and dually for homology. Proof. Note that deformation retracts to via ,
where the second isomorphism is from the isomorphism for along with the UCTthe UCT. On the other hand, since is contractible, while for . Thus, the statement follows from the LES of pairs. ***Note that explicitly the factor of comes in the LES from the associated SESThus, when , an orientation corresponds to choosing an orientation on either with an outward or inward normal.Let's now generalize to a vector bundle of fiber dimension , and give a first naive definition of orientation.Orientation on a Vector Bundle #1 An orientation for is a function assigning an orientation to each fiber of subject to the following local compatibility: For every , there exists a local trivialization with and such that for each fiber over , the homomorphism is orientation preserving. In terms of cohomology this says that to each fiber there is assigned a preferred generator The local compatibility condition implies that for each point in the base space, there exists a neighborhood and a cohomology class so that for each fiber over , the restriction In particular, these glue to give a Thom class . Moving forward we will write for without the zero section.Alternatively, recall that if is a vector bundle over of rank , we have its exterior power which is a line bundle over . Then a compatible choice of orientations is equivalent to a compatible choice of non-zero elements in the fibers for . Thus, is orientable in the above sense if and only if admits a non-vanishing section, and hence is a trivial line bundle. In this case, any two non-vanishing sections are said to be equivalent if there exists , , such that ( can be chosen to be smooth if and are). This gives a second definition for orientations:Orientation on a Vector Bundle #2 An orientation for is an equivalence class of non-vanishing sections . When , for a smooth manifold, this recovers the usual orientation of manifolds.
Using our cocycle classification of bundlescocycle classification of bundles, a vector bundle being orientable can be equivalently phrased as asking for the existence of a cocycle taking values in . This is the first case of a more general pattern of lifting the cocycle group for a bundle to give it additional structure.Orientation via Cocycles Let be a vector bundle of rank on a space admitting partitions of unity (e.g. paracompact Hausdorff). Then admits a non-vanishing section if and only if admits a description in terms of cocycles taking values in . Proof. First, suppose is orientable so we have a global non-vanishing section . Say that a local frame is positively oriented if for all , for . All local frames are either positively or negatively oriented, and multiplying by in one of the coordinates we can always replace a negatively oriented local frame by a positively oriented local frame. Then we obtain our desired cover by positive local trivializations.Conversely, if such local trivializations with cocycles exist, then we can define by taking a partition of unity and summing the induced orientations on the . *** Another example of this phenomena occurs with Riemannian metrics, where admits a Riemannian metric if and only if it admits a cocycle with values in the orthogonal group . Over paracompact spaces this always holds via a partition of unity argument. Alternatively, it can be shown that , the polar decomposition, where are the positive definite symmetric matrices contractible?.Warning A vector bundle over a manifold can be orientable without or being orientable. 2-3 property for orientability Let be a rank vector bundle over . Then if two of are orientable, then so is the third. Proof.
Step 1: Suppose is a short exact sequence of vector bundles over with constant rank maps, where , , and . We start by proving that the 2-of-3 property holds for short exact sequences. From our construction of local trivializations in Operations on Vector Bundles > ^7ff753Operations on Vector Bundles > ^7ff753 we can find a cover of with trivialization on that extends to a trivialization of , such that gives trivializations for , so that if are the cocycles for and are the cocycles for , then are cocycles for . Then the result follows since .Step 2: Consider the zero section . Then we have a diagram
so that is an epimorphism of vector bundles. Then we have a short exact sequence of vector bundles over . Note that since is an embedded submanifold for all , and is a linear subspace, for all , and these assemble to give a bundle map
where is given by the identity for the second factor and the composite for the first, so that we get a unique map of bundles over . It follows by rank considerations that , so we get a short exact sequence of vector bundles over .Step 3: is orientable if and only if is orientable combined with the short exact sequence in step 2 and the 2-of-3 property in step 1 now implies the result. The forward implication is clear since , so it suffices to assume is orientable. However, this will follow from the homotopy invariance of pullbacks of vector bundles, proved below, and the fact that deformation retracts onto under the zero section, so that we have a pullback composite diagram
*** ToDo: Show how this notion of orientation is equivalent to the cohomology one We now restrict to the cohomological description of orientations.Matrix Acting on Cohomology For , is given by multiplication by . Proof.

Before stating our generalized definition orientations, let's recall the notion of Thom Space from Topological Basics of SpectraTopological Basics of Spectra:Thom Space The Thom space of the rank vector bundle , denoted , is given by taking the one-point compactification of the fibers to give a sphere bundle whose fibers are homeomorphic to , and then collapsing the subspace containing all the newly created points at to a single point. In other words, Intuition: is just the vector bundle with a single additional point that can be reached by going to along any of the fibers of .Lemma: Alternate Description of Thom Space There is a homeomorphism , where is the unit disc bundle and is the unit sphere bundle, for any fixed choice of Riemannian metric on . Proof.
Fix a Riemannian metric on (this is always possible when the base space admits numerable covers, e.g. paracompact Hausdorff spaces, which all CW complexes are, c.f. existence of Riemannian metricsexistence of Riemannian metrics). For each , we have a natural map given by for , and for . These maps are continuous, and assemble into a bundle morphism , which in a local Riemannian chart is given by where is the quotient map followed by the natural isomorphism . Composing with the quotient to the Thom space we obtain a map of bundles which induces a homeomorphism , as desired. *** When is the trivial bundle, the Thom space is so when is non-trivial we can think of the Thom space as a twisted suspension of .Thom Space of Exterior Sum If and are vector bundles of constant finite rank, then we have a homeomorphism where the basepoint is given by the unique point at . Proof. Note that where we use to denote the one-point compactification. In particular, we see that , as desired. *** Thom Space of Whitney Sum with Trivial Bundle If is a finite rank vector bundle and is the rank trivial bundle over , then Proof. Note that where . In other words, Then quotienting out by we have that as desired. *** If we make a spectrum by formally de-suspending , this should correspond to subtracting off a trivial bundle. Recall that a virtual bundle over a compact space can always be written as a difference of a vector bundle by trivial bundle. Then we define the Thom spectrum of as the desuspended suspension spectrum
We also write for this spectrum. If is another presentation of the virtual bundle, then , so that by the computation for the Thom space of a Whitney Sumthe computation for the Thom space of a Whitney Sum, for , so that the spectra are stably equivalent. Thus, is well-defined up to stable equivalence of spectra.If is a closed manifold with tangent bundle , the virtual bundle , where is the normal bundle of some embedding . Thus, its Thom spectrum is stably equivalent to Since and are always cofibrations, instead of working with relative cohomology we can work with absolute cohomology, where This allows us to generalize orientations to multiplicative cohomology theories (c.f. )Cohomology Orientation on a Vector Bundle Let be a multiplicative cohomology theory and let be a vector bundle of rank . Then an -orientation or -Thom class on is an element of degree , in the reduced -cohomology ring of the Thom space of such that for every point , its restriction along is a generator in the sense that it is of the form for a unit in the ring and the image of the multiplicative unit under the suspension isomorphism . In other words, is a generator of as a -module.

In this case the definition of orientation reduces to the following:-orientation An -orientation (or -Thom class) on is such that generates for all . In this note we introduce some of the basic theory for cohomology, following the work in Hatcher[1]. Specifically, we will be illustrating the tools that cohomology gives us which aren't visible in homology (or are less straight forward to study in homology). Some of these features include cohomology groups, the ring structure on cohomology, and its Poincare duality characteristics.The contravariance of the cohomology functors make them much more accessible to these algebraic constructions we are going to investigate. However, as we will see, under certain assumptions the homology groups determine the cohomology groups.The main difficulty with defining a product on homology is that we want a map , which requires a map , but no such canonical map exists which doesn't lose information from one of the factors of . On the other hand, having a map is the same as a map , for which there is a natural such map, the diagonal. Such a map gives a variety of useful properties in cohomologyIn both the case of homology and cohomology we also have a cross product map (and similarly for cohomology) which in cellular homology sends cells of and of to the product cell in the product CW complex .Note that we have quite a bit of freedom when working with cohomology groups. In particular, for any abelian group , we can consider cohomology with coefficients in by forming the dual complex of a chain complex with respect to a group . We will begin by establishing that there, in a sense, is a universal such coefficient group, namely , and in what ways it is universal.To begin, let be a chain complex of finitely generated free abelian groups, . Taking duals this gives a short exact sequence in the opposite direction We then obtain a long exact sequence of homology groups for these cochain complexes, where we have used the fact that the homology of a complex with all boundary maps zero is just the groups in the complex. In this note we introduce the notion of de Rham cohomology and prove some of its important and basic properties. We aim to focus on intuition and examples in these notes, following the work of Bott and Tu in[1].We will begin with defining and computing examples for the de Rham cohomology on Euclidean space. For this purpose, let denote linear coordinates on , and let denote the -algebra generated by symbols under the relations for all and . Explicitly, is the alternating tensor algebra, or exterior algebra, on , As a vector space, has basis and , such that . Let denote the -algebra of functions on . Then we can define the algebra of differential forms on by tensoring: This implies that any form in this algebra can be uniquely written as , where the are functions. This algebra is in fact graded, with multiplication graded-commutative, in the sense that if is a -form and is a -form, then . Additionally, the algebra of differential forms is naturally equipped with a degree vector space homomorphism, , where for , and , We refer to the degree-1 map as the exterior differentiation on differential forms.Example The exterior derivative can be realized as a generalization of other notions, such as curl and divergence. Consider . Then and are 1-dimensional, while and are 3-dimensional over . Because of this, we can identify -forms and -forms, via , and -forms and -forms with vector fields by and . Then, on functions sends -forms to their gradients, on -forms maps -forms to their curl (when considering them as vector fields), and on -forms acts by sending the -form to the divergence of its associated vector field. Let's start looking at some properties of this algebra with its exterior derivation.Exterior Derivative Satisfies Anti-Jacobian Identity If is a -form and is a -form, then Proof. Indeed, for a function smooth we have which is zero since the partials of commute while the differentials anti-commute. More generally, we have that We refer to this resulting co-chain complex as the de Rham complex on , with its cohomology being the de Rham Cohomology of . Geometrically, an element of the -th de Rham cohomology of is represented by a cohomology class of closed -forms, which differ only by exact forms. One can think of the closed forms as being differential equations in a precise sense. Note that we could have made these definitions for any open subset, , obtaining a resulting complex with associated de Rham cohomology, .In general, the de Rham cohomology of is relatively easy to compute. Indeed, is simply connected, in fact contractible, and so a closed -form must always be exact. For 1-forms this can be derived from the fundamental theorem of calculus, while similar properties holds for higher forms. This is due to a more general fact that de Rham cohomology is actually a topological invariant.Another form of de Rham cohomology can be obtained by restricting our algebra to the algebra of smooth functions with compact support. This defines the compactly supported de Rham complex with cohomology . In this case we obtain an interesting kind of duality, with being in all degrees except , where it is . Before doing this we should expand our definition of de Rham complexes to differentiable manifolds more generally. To begin, consider a smooth map . We have a natural pullback operation on , , via To expand this to -forms more generally, and also in such a way that defines a map of co-chain complexes, we give where is the th component of the function . Using pullback to apply changes of coordinates, we can see that the exterior derivative is independent of the coordinate system on we are working with.Differential Forms on a Manifold A differential form on a manifold is a collection of forms for in the atlas defining , which are compatible in the sense that for any two opens and in the atlas, with and , The exterior derive and wedge product are defined by extending the definitions on the individual opens in the atlas. Further, becomes a contravariant functor on the category of smooth manifolds and smooth maps using pullback. Recall that manifolds have partitions of unity, where a partition of unity for a manifold with respect to an open cover is a collection of non-negative functions such that , is locally finite, and We can further assume the supports of the are compact, if we wish, provided we possibly use a different index set.To begin suppose is a manifold and for and open. Then we have inclusions Applying we get the restrictions Taking the difference of the last two maps we obtain a short exact sequence of co-chain complexesThis is a special case of the statement that forms a flasque sheaf on . Indeed, differential forms are uniquely determined by their restrictions to open covers, so the first map is injective and the sequence is exact at the middle term. To show surjectivity of the last map take a partition of unity subordinate to the open cover . Then any -form on can be given by where we can view and as -forms on and , respectively.

Thus, is on and on .Support of a Form Let be a -form on a manifold . For any we have a natural map given by evaluating coefficients at . Then the support of the -form is defined to be We can also obtain a Mayer-Vietoris sequence when working with compactly supported de Rham cohomology. Here we have to be a little careful since in general pulling back a form with compact support along a smooth map need not produce a form also with compact support. However, if we restrict to a certain subclass of smooth maps we can obtain a well-defined functor . In this case our Mayer-Vietoris sequence looks like which gives a long exact sequence on cohomology.Differential forms provide a wide range of tools. One of the most important such tools is their use in characterizing orientability of manifolds and the ability to integrate against them. Proof. Let be a global nowhere vanishing -form associated to the orientation . Let be another oriented atlas for this orientation with partition of unity . reading-notes/homotopy-theory/topologica.title: Basics of Homology - Simplicial and Singular Homology
reading-notes/homotopy-theory/topologica.description:
In this note we introduce basics concepts of homology focusing on the notions of simplicial and singular homology, following the approach of Hatcher[1]. Homology is an algebraic homotopy invariant of spaces which are incredibly important, largely due to their better computability over higher homotopy groups. In particular, simplicial, or sometimes called cellular homology, gives an explicit algorithm for computing all homology groups for a CW complex from the combinatorial data of its cell structure, with the chain complex defining the homology groups encoding cells in each dimension and attaching data in the boundary maps of the chain complex.The fundamental building block for simplicial homology is the -simplex. In this note we aim to provide a basic introduction to the theory of fiber bundles, and the special role principal bundles play in their classification. These notes are primarily adapted from Rui's Math 519 course notes in Spring 2025 at UIUC, with additional perspectives from Jake Rasmussen's Math 526 in Fall 2024.To begin we'll start with the theory of fiber bundles and locally trivial fibrations. Throughout let denote the ambient category of topological objects (e.g. topological spaces, compactly generated weak Hausdorff spaces, possibly infinite dimensional smooth manifolds, etc.).Locally Trivial Fibration A locally trivial fibration with fiber type is a map such that for every , there exists an open neighborhood of of and an isomorphism in . Note that if is a trivializing cover for a fiber bundle with fiber type , then the transition function determines a cocycle (which is a map in if it is a cartesian closed category, which we assume moving forward).If in addition is a group object such that we have an effective group action (i.e. the induced map is a monomorphism), then we can add the requirement that the cocycle takes values in the image of . This leads to the notion of fiber bundle.Fiber Bundle A fiber bundle with fiber and structure group consists of a locally trivial fibration with fiber type , an effective left -action , and a collection of locally trivializing charts such that There exists in , such that The collection is maximal in the sense that if is a trivializing chart such that there exists with , then . When is a vector space and , this definition recovers the notion of a vector bundle. When , with the free transitive action by left translation, this definition encodes the notion of a -principal bundle. A morphism of -fiber bundles is a map in such that for all , the induced map given by pulling back along fibers is a map of -spaces. In particular, if and are trivializations for and , with , then being -equivariant implies that for each , the induced map must satisfy , so that we get an induced map such that .Now, we say that -cocycles and for covers of are equivalent if there exists a common refinement for the open covers together with maps such that for all , If denotes the set of equivalence classes of -cocycles, then we have a one-to-one correspondence between elements of and isomorphism classes of -fiber bundles over with fiber fixed. Explicitly, given a -cocycle for a cover of , the associated -fiber bundle is Construction: Reduction of Structure Group Given a closed subgroup , we say that the structure group of a -fiber bundle can be reduced to if there exists a cocycle for with values in . Reduction Examples A -fiber bundle is trivial (i.e. isomorphic to ) if and only if the structure group can be reduced to . For a vector bundle, the structure group can be reduced to if and only if it is orientable if and only if it admits a metric if and only if it is orientable and admits a metric Notice that the cocycle description does not reference the fiber . As a consequence of the previous correspondence, we then have the following: To every -fiber bundle with fiber , there is associated a -principal bundle (defined up to isomorphism) Alternatively, to every -principal bundle, , if is a space with effective -action , we have an associated -fiber bundle with fiber . Further, and is a -cocycle associated to the -principal bundle , so that , thenso that corresponds to the same cocycle as .Theorem: Fiber Bundles Via Principal Bundles Via Cocycles Let be agroup, let be a space with an effective -action, and let . Then the composite of bijections can be given explicitly by sending a -principal bundle to the -fiber bundle . This perspective plays an essential role due to the simplicity with which -Principal bundles can be described, and the number of classifying space results associated with them.First, let's recall some constructions of -principal bundles when is or .Theorem: Slice Theorem Let be a proper action. For each there exists an embedded submanifold containing and satisfying is -invariant , where is the orbit at in For and such that , . Proof. TBL *** Theorem: Smooth Structure on Quotient If is a free and proper action, then the quotient space has a unique (smooth) structure such that the quotient map is a submersion. Proof. TBL *** Theorem: Quotient Principal Bundle Let be a free and proper right action. Then is a -principal bundle. Further, every -principal bundle is of this form. Proof. TBL *** Thus, we can identify -principal bundles with free and proper right actions , so that for any left action , we get another free and proper action , where , so that quotienting by this action gives the associated bundle .Associated Bundles The trivial -principal bundle is , with associated bundle for any action the trivial -bundle . Homogeneous spaces: For a closed subgroup, is a principal -bundle Covering Spaces: A universal covering is a principal -bundle . board-talks/lectures/tfts-via-cyclic-and.title: TFTs via Cyclic and Modular Infinity Operads
board-talks/lectures/tfts-via-cyclic-and.description:
Abstract Modular (-)operads provide a (coherent) algebraic way to encode the gluing operations of connected surfaces. In particular, the bordism ()-category provides a special kind of modular operad whose algebras are topological field theories, where taking algebras in the symmetric monoidal -category of -linear categories recovers Segal's notion of modular functors, used in his approach to conformal field theories. If instead the algebras are taken in the derived category of chain complexes over , then one obtains a structure closely related to Witten's notion of cohomological field theories. In this talk we aim to provide an example driven introduction to modular (-)operads and their appearance in the study of topological field theories. Goal: Provide an example driven introduction to modular -operads in the study of TFTs using the language of Segal conditions.In this talk we aim to provide an example driven introduction to modular -operads and their application in the study of TFTs. In order to accomplish this we use the language of Segal conditions for -operads, which provides an elegant generalization to modular and cyclic -operads. The primary references for this note are the talk notes of Steinebrunner[1] and Marci Robertson in the Copenhagen Masterclass[2]. We also pull some descriptions from[3].Note: We will work 1-categorically for the most part, though wherever appears it can be replaced by the -category of spaces to obtain the -categorical version, modulo the inclusion of certain completeness restrictions.When working with higher algebraic structure, especially algebraic structure which is homotopical in nature, such as that associated with cohomological field theories, it is beneficial to have concrete combinatorial descriptions of your data for the sake of computations. Note that (-)categories are modelled on the idea that we have elementary structures, given by objects and arrows , and that we have compositional structure allowing us to build an arrow from a sequence of arrows , where when this is the same as an object . One can think of a category as a collection of sets indexed by these structures, which corresponds to a functor , satisfying the additional gluing requirementKey Idea: Algebraic/Categorical structures are given by specifying data on elementary shapes, and then specifying structure by relations on gluings of the elementary shapes.The idea of operads come from generalizing this perspective to the structure needed to encode common occurrences of algebraic data:Example (i) A monoid consists of an object , a multiplication operation , and a unit operation for the multiplication such that it satisfies associativity and unitality (ii) A left module consists a pair of a monoid object and an object together with additional operation satisfying associativity With these examples in mind, a first approach to studying algebraic structures could be to take our basic shapes to be trees:
Here the basic shape of an edge represents our objects, while corollas between edges represent our morphisms. It turns out that if we take the input edges to a corolla to be ordered this gives us non-symmetric operads, while if we our edges to be non-ordered this gives us symmetric operads. In this talk the main important case will be that of symmetric operads, which are indexed by the category of trees. A tree will be described by a polynomial^ffbb7c where is the set of edges, is the set of vertices, is the set of vertices with a choice of incoming edge, and are the natural projections, and sends a vertex to its unique outgoing edge. Note: All vertices have a unique outgoing edge, though not all vertices need have an incoming edge (and edges need not have two vertices)
Tree A tree is a diagram of shape TFTs via Cyclic and Modular Infinity Operads > ^ffbb7cTFTs via Cyclic and Modular Infinity Operads > ^ffbb7c of finite sets such that is injective is injective and there exists a unique edge not in the image of
define by , for all we have for some A subtree inclusion is a diagram This defines the inert Dendroidal category . Given a tree we can obtain another polynomialwhere is the set of subtrees of , and is the set of subtrees of with a marked leaf. Then one can describe maps in as a map of such polynomials, which is determined by where we send vertices in . The inert morphisms are the subtree inclusions while the active morphisms are those preserving the boundary (i.e. leaves go to leaves and roots go to roots).Example For , the -corolla is the tree while the plain edge is the tree We write for the full subcategory spanned by those elementary objects. An operad is then a pre-sheaf which preserves the gluing data, which is to say that for a tree , we haveOperads are meant to encode coherent operations for algebraic structure. To obtain algebraic objects with these given operations we need to define the notion of algebras over an operad. For this we use the fact that (symmetric) monoidal categories are important examples of operads. Indeed, for a (symmetric) monoidal category its underlying operad sends the plain edge to the set of objects in and the -corolla to the set with fibersAlgebras Over an Operad An algebra over an operad valued in a (symmetric) monoidal category is a map of operads We write for the category of -algebras in . Let's considered the case of a non-coloured operad , so that . Then an -algebra in consists of an object together with for each -ary operation in , an operationwhere if is a symmetric operad these maps are required to be -fixed points in .Little Disks Operad For each we have the little -disks operad has -ary operations given by embeddings In higher categorical contexts these operads interpolate between associative monoids and commutative monoids . These are actually an example of objects with more algebraic structure than operads. Such additional algebraic structure is important for specifying structures like Hopf algebras which come with both operations as well as co-operations . A straightforward generalization of the diagram shapes for operads then leads us to the notion of (symmetric) properads, where instead of rooted trees we look at directed acyclic graphs. To define directed acyclic graphs it will be helpful to use the notion of undirected graphs:Undirected Graphs with Loose Ends An undirected graph with loose ends is a diagram of finite sets where is a fixed-point free involution and the map is a monomorphism. Here is the set of arcs of , is the set of vertices, and is the boundary of , while the set of edges is the set of pairs (i.e. is the set of -orbits). To each undirected graph we can associate its geometric realization, and we say is connected if this topological space is connected. For two connected undirected graphs , an embedding consists of a map of diagrams such that is injective, preserves the involution, and arises as the pullback of along . We write for the set of isomorphism classes of embeddings of graphs in . Note: This is analogous to the inert maps for trees, though we don't have an additional map from vertices back to edges since there is no notion of an inward or outward edge We write for the set of isomorphism classes of embeddings of graphs in . We can identify the set of edges of with the set of embeddings of in and the set of vertices with the set of embeddings of for all . In particular we have inclusions .Graph Map Let be connected undirected graphs. A graph map consists of (i) an involution preserving function (ii) a function such that (a) sends edges to edges (b) preserves unions and takes vertex disjoint pairs to vertex disjoint pairs (c) is boundary-compatible The category then has connected undirected graphs as objects and graph maps as morphisms which compose by composing the component functions.Active-Inert Factorization A graph map in is active if , and inert if the composite factors through . In the latter case we obtain the notion of an embedding discussed previously. We can then define the directed graphs via the pullback:Directed Acyclic Graphs The category of directed graphs is the pullback so that a directed graph is a graph together with a splitting of as . The category of directed acyclic graphs is the full subcategory on those directed graphs that do not have directed cycles. The elementary objects of are the directed edge and the directed corollas for all (here is obtained from by orienting it in such a way that it has incoming and outgoing edges). The induced active and inert morphisms have Segal objects the properads.An important example of a properad is that associated to a symmetric monoidal -category . The value at a graph is the space of all labellings of by in the following sense: A labelling assigns to each edge of an object and to each vertex a morphism whose source is the tensor product of labels edges entering and whose target is the tensor product of labels of edges exiting . Functoriality with respect to inert maps is given by forgetting the labelling associated to pre-images of . The functoriality with respect to edge contractions is given by composing morphisms, and the functoriality with respect to subdivisions is by introducing identity morphisms. Monoidal Envelope for Properads There is an adjunction that has properties discussed below. To begin describing , recall that the free commutative monoid monad is defined byThen the objects of are freely generated by the colours of whereas the morphisms are freely generated by the operations of :

These notes are for a 30~40 minute talk on semi-additivity as appearing in Sections 2.1 and 2.2 of the paper Ambidexterity and Height[1], which was given as part of an Ambidexterity seminar at UIUC in Fall 2025. In the paper Carmeli, Schlank, and Yanovski use the theory of higher semi-additivity to abstract and generalize the notion of height appearing in chromatic homotopy theory. The -self maps used in the definition of chromatic height are instead replaced by the cardinalities of certain -finite spaces (to be discussed soon).
Further, the semi-additive height filtration introduced in the paper refines the inclusion , which is now known to be strict for . We also pull some ideas from later work due to Cnossen et al. on Parameterized Semi-additivity[2], and earlier work on applications of ambidexterity to chromatic homotopy theory[3].Let's begin by recalling the notation used in the paper:Conventions: will denote the sub--category spanned by stable -categories and exact functors. Similarly, we write and write for the unit (called the diagonal) Given a map of spaces , and , we write for the homotopy fiber of over . board-talks/seminars/ambidexterity-semin.title: Reading Plan for Ambidexterity Seminar (Fall 2025)
board-talks/seminars/ambidexterity-semin.description:
We will be starting with section 2 of Shachar et al.'s paper on Ambidexterity and Height[1], before moving into the initial main reference, which will be the first part of Bastiaan Cnossen's thesis[2], with other references/possible directions being Hilman, Kirstein, and Kremer's generalization of twisted ambidexterity in[3], as well as applications of ordinary ambidexterity to chromatic homotopy theory in[4]. Depending on interest we could also look into the related notions of higher semi-additivity appearing in[5] and[6].
September 15th: Sections 2.1-2.2 of[1-1] (Ea/E)
September 22nd: Sections 2.3-3.2 of[1-2] (Ea/E) September 29th: Parameterized Infinity Categories (Fredrick) October 6th: Parameterized Higher Semiadditivity (Fredrick) October 13th: Twisted Ambidexterity (Fredrick) October 20th: No Talk October 27th: Equivariance in Twisted Ambidexterity I (Yigal Kamel) November 3rd: Equivariance in Twisted Ambidexterity II (Yigal Kamel) November 10th: Twisted Ambidexterity and Poincare Duality (Ea/E) November 17th: TBD November 24th: Fall Break December 1st: TBD December 8th: TBD Parameterized equivariant things Elliptic cohomology connections (might use some of the chromatic applications) Proof of Relative Poincare duality in and relation to twisted ambidexterity (Bastiaan's thesis) (for Spring possibly) Twisted Bredon-Browder Injection and Poincare Rigidity via twisted ambidexterity (Parametrised Poincare duality and Equivariant Fixed Points Methods) Sheaves with transfers and applications to Global Homotopy Theory (Parametrized (Higher) Semiadditivity and the Universality of Spans) 1-Semiadditivity implying that admits a lift to (Ambidexterity in Chromatic Homotopy Theory) For a weak ring (not necessarily -local), is 1-semiadditive if and only if it is -semiadditive (Ambidexterity in Chromatic Homotopy Theory) For stably presentable -local -categories with bounded stable height, 1-semiadditivity implies -semiadditivity (Ambidexterity and Height)
Carmeli, Shachar, Tomer M. Schlank, and Lior Yanovski. “Ambidexterity and Height.” arXiv:2007.13089. Preprint, arXiv, September 25, 2020. https://doi.org/10.48550/arXiv.2007.13089.↩︎↩︎↩︎
Bastiaan Cnossen: Twisted ambidexterity in equivariant homotopy theory: Two approaches, https://hdl.handle.net/20.500.11811/11281, (2024)↩︎
Hilman, K., Kirstein, D., Kremer, C.: Parametrised Poincaré duality and equivariant fixed points methods, http://arxiv.org/abs/2405.17641, (2024)↩︎
Carmeli, Shachar, Tomer M. Schlank, and Lior Yanovski. “Ambidexterity in Chromatic Homotopy Theory.” arXiv:1811.02057. Preprint, arXiv, September 16, 2020. https://doi.org/10.48550/arXiv.1811.02057.↩︎
Cnossen, Bastiaan, Tobias Lenz, and Sil Linskens. “Parametrized (Higher) Semiadditivity and the Universality of Spans.” arXiv:2403.07676. Preprint, arXiv, September 27, 2024. https://doi.org/10.48550/arXiv.2403.07676.↩︎
Harpaz, Yonatan. “Ambidexterity and the Universality of Finite Spans.” Proceedings of the London Mathematical Society 121, no. 5 (2020): 1121–70. https://doi.org/10.1112/plms.12367.↩︎

info_showOrphanNodes.description: Show nodes that are not connected to any other nodes.

info_showAttachments.description: Show attachments like images and PDFs as nodes in the graph.

info_allowGlobalGraph.description: Allow the user to view the global graph of all nodes.

info_allowExpand.description: Allow the user to pop-out the graph view to take up the whole screen

info_attractionForce.description: How much should linked nodes attract each other? This will make the graph appear more clustered.

info_linkLength.description: How long should the links between nodes be? The shorter the links the more connected nodes will cluster together.

info_repulsionForce.description: How much should nodes repel each other? This will make disconnected parts more spread out.

info_centralForce.description: How much should nodes be attracted to the center? This will make the graph appear more dense and circular.

info_edgePruning.description: Edges with a length above this threshold will not be rendered, however they will still contribute to the simulation. This can help large tangled graphs look more organised. Hovering over a node will still display these links.

info_minNodeRadius.description: How small should the smallest nodes be? The smaller a node is the less it will attract other nodes.

info_maxNodeRadius.description: How large should the largest nodes be? Nodes are sized by how many links they have. The larger a node is the more it will attract other nodes. This can be used to create a good grouping around the most important nodes.

info_allowResizing.description: Whether or not to allow the sidebars to be resized

info_allowCollapsing.description: Whether or not to allow the sidebars to be collapsed

info_rightDefaultWidth.description: The default width of the right sidebar

info_leftDefaultWidth.description: The default width of the left sidebar
